newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Optus sees 8 mln Australian mobiles by 2000.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Optus sees 8 mln Australian mobiles by 2000.

text.p: Optus Communications Pty Ltd said on Wednesday it estimated that Australia would have about eight million customers of mobile phones by the year 2000, when the country completely phases out the analogue mobile phone network.
Optus chief operating officer Phil Jacobs told reporters Australia currently has 4.5 million mobile phone customers, with about 40 percent on the digital network.

"Our estimates are based on projected growth rates that we will get a penetration rate of 40 percent of population, which will be about eight million total mobile users in Australia," Jacobs told a news conference.
Jacobs said this forecast did not represent a staturation point in the mobile market.

Australia currently had 4.5 million mobile phone customers or about 25 percent of the nation's 18 million population, making it one of the world's highest users of mobile phone per head of population.
Jacobs said there were about 100,000 new customers per month to Australia's mobile network.
Revenue from Optus' mobile business jumped 58 percent to A$530 million for the six months ended December 31, 1996, the biggest rise amongst the group's businesses.
Optus earlier reported a net profit of A$58.9 million for the six months ended December 31, 1996, compared with A$7.1 million a year earlier.
Optus is owned 25 percent by Mayne Nickless Ltd and 24.5 percent each by Cable and Wireless Plc of the United Kingdom and U.S. carrier BellSouth Corp Inc.
The remainder is owned by Australian institutions.
